results.content:
I love the idea of learning Bootstrap by developing several different websites. Most other courses on Bootstrap are little more than what you can freely walk through on the Bootstrap website or 5 minutes of searching on YouTube -- so kudos for the approach. Few courses venture beyond hello world examples, at least this one attempts to create real world websites with Bootstrap.

However, if you are new to HTML, CSS, or JavaScript -- this isn't the course for you -- at all. The instructor is inconsistent about explaining the code used -- even Bootstrap specific stuff. Sometimes he does a good job, other times you are just watching him copy and paste code from the Bootstrap website or other locations without much (if any) explanation.

Also, the quality of the editing is much to be desired. There are several times where something goes wrong and the fumbling around isn't edited out. I'm all for teaching how to debug and troubleshooting -- but it has to be done on purpose -- or at least appear that way. The current approach, at least, looks like the instructor didn't prepare for the recording. There should be no surprises during recording a course. I haven't gone through a section yet without major mistakes discovered along the way. I appreciate the instructor admitting the issue and shows how to resolve it -- which was cute the first few times, but it is down right annoying after awhile.

Oh yeah, register your software before you record a course you charge for -- Just sayin. It's unprofessional and tacky.

Super high priced courses should have an unmistakably professional tone to them and this one fails to deliver on that. Thus, the course far from worth the listing price (which is the norm on Udemy). However, if you can get over the imperfections and can get this for one of the many Udemy discounts -- it's worth it. Just keep in mind this course isn't worth the list price so any discount ratio is deceptive.

Update: I've updated the review to 3 stars primarily because the instructor provides incremental project files along the way -- which is very useful and is probably the best feature of the course.

results.content:
I found this course to be kinda meh.  The vast majority of it is watching someone else code and just copying what you're seeing. It's not teaching you how to use bootstrap effectively.  I mean, examples are good, and I definitely picked up a few things from the courses, but I spent so much time pausing the videos so I could understand the feature being used.  

A couple other things that irked me... I found some of the instructor's approaches to setting up the CSS in some projects to be more complicated than needed, but I guess that's just preference.  Also, the complete lack of mentioning the option to use command line Sass was a bit annoying.  That whole section on installing Java and that client tool for compiling Sass isn't really needed.  I feel like a lot of us are probably setting up completely command line builds.

All in all, I did learn some things, and the number of different types of projects is really nice.  It's a lot of material and I'd probably still buy the course again.  I just wish there was more explanation of the various components.

results.content:
I was initially interested in this course because of it's project approach to learning Bootstrap.  I have completed other courses that provided a solid introduction to Bootstrap, and my goal was for this to be my next step.

Unfortunately this course has so far fallen short of my expectations.  I typically read through the comments of the various lectures because there is often great information in there, and I was troubled when in Section 2 people were commenting the author was needlessly duplicating functionality already in Bootstrap.  After a little research I found they were indeed right, and I started to question the quality and skill level of the instructor.

In Section 3 the author dives right into SASS with virtually no explanation of what a preprocessing language is or how it's used.  The instructor noted the course requires just basic knowledge of HTML and CSS web development, and this seemed very out of place.  Some students asked why SASS was being taught, and unfortunately the instructor's responses were very generic (SASS is something you can use if you need it), and not really helpful.

The production quality is average when compared to most other courses.  It was clear the instructor did not know how the lectures would be broken up prior to recording, so you pretty much have one giant lecture abruptly broken up into smaller lectures.  The instructor's delivery is also boring and monotone.  Worst of all, if you are teaching a course, for the love of everything that is holy REGISTER THE SOFTWARE YOU ARE USING TO TEACH.  It's extremely unprofessional to watch your instructor click a "Register Later" button in the middle of a course.

Honestly, I would not recommend this course to someone that is new to Bootstrap and is looking for clear learning path.  I don't mind the issues as much because I'm in sponge mode right now regarding Bootstrap and just want to see how people are building sites.  I also don't mind having to pause and take multi-hour detours to read up on something the instructor doesn't explain (i.e. preprocessors) since it helps me learn.  However, I know this will not suit a lot of learners.

If you want to learn Bootstrap better this is a great choice.

results.content:
I wrote an earlier 2-star review, but as I paid for it, I've tried to get what I can out of it. Sadly, the more lectures I watch, the worse I feel about the course and the instructor.

1. The instructor does not know his own projects very well. He's constantly doing something, saying "And now you see...wait, why didn't that work? Hold on....let me see....." 

2. Some of the "solutions" he gives for these situations are actually Very. Bad. Practice. (like using "!important") or just kludgy.

3. He has a fundamentally flawed understanding of Bootstrap 3. He makes the comment several times that "We'll adjust that for smaller screens later" showing a complete lack of understanding that Bootstrap is mobile-first.

4. When people post questions on the discussion groups, he does one of two things: either he gives a curt reply that's usually not helpful or shows any willingness to help the poster or he gives no reply at all. This latter happens all too often. What's the point of discussion groups if the instructor is not present?

5. The course is very disorganized. He introduces topics like SASS/SCSS in one section, but then doesn't continue with it in later sections. He also doesn't really explain why such tools are useful. And since he doesn't continue with them, it leaves me asking "Why did I learn this? Do I need it?"

6. He doesn't know the tools he's using/teaching very well. He doesn't know his editor very well, he doesn't know CSS very well (several CSS rules that he writes are either outright wrong or Very. Bad. Practice.)

I'm struggling to find something *good* to say about this course or this instructor, but I'm at a loss.

The 30-day money-back guarantee is not useful for me, as I bought 4-5 courses at one time and did not start this course immediately, therefore by the time I had started it and realized I and many others were having problems and then I investigated further, the 30-day clock had run out.

So, thanks for nothing. I'm glad I didn't pay full price, but honestly I wish I hadn't paid anything at all. But, even if it were free,  I still wouldn't recommend it to any one.

results.content:
I took this course to see how various types of websites are designed with Bootstrap and I am very pleased with the content. I learned a lot about the grid system as well as how to structure projects and implement many of the Bootstrap controls.

As a bonus I was introduced to LESS and SASS CSS preprocessors, Javascript, and cool free components such as font-awesome, google fonts, etc.

This course delivers in content and just like other project oriented courses it comes up short in explanations. With this course you will have to do a bit of googling in order to get the most of out it but its well worth the effort.

I gave this 4.5 stars though for a reason. The main reason is the instructor is quick to jump to previewing the project the moment he finishes typing in his editor. His editor tooltips at times obscures what he is typing compounding the issue. The real winner though is when he pastes content in and removes content leaving you at times searching where to place or remove blocks. The other annoying thing is he never displays his editor in fullscreen mode. 

All of these issues though were overshadowed for me based on the quality of the content. It was really a tough decision to give this course 4.5 stars based on the video presentation however the audio is clear and Brad put together 10 exceptionally feature rich projects.

I strongly encourage you to take this course if you are like myself willing to overlooking the shortcomings, willing to put in the work to understand why the projects are organized this way in bootstrap, and are really fast to hit the rewind button. I am extremely pleased with the course content and kudos to Brad for adding so much to each project! You will be hard pressed to find a better projects course for Bootstrap in my opinion.

results.content:
What I really liked about this course is the great selection of useful projects. The variety is great and make good examples for showing off the various Bootstrap features. The pace was good for me through most of it... a little fast when he  copy/pasted content and expected us to stop the video and catch up, but not a big deal. I enjoyed the course and recommend it for those wanting to expose themselves to a variety of examples of what you can do with Bootstrap.

Ways to improve this course and get my 5th star:
1. Cover more of the key features of Bootstrap (BS) theory, showing illustrations in your slides to help the understanding. More conceptual explanations up front of introducing new BS features
2. There were places where added BS classes to tags and not explain why he was adding them. He does sometimes but many times not. In some cases you can make assumptions and figure it out intuitively why, but for those who don't pick up on that or where it's not obvious, more explanation of the why you chose a class to add.
3. I wish that once SASS/LESS were introduced that they were used from then on. It would have helped with the styling for the Business Theme for example, where the #myCarousel had a long stack of various styling variations. Embedding them in a hierarchy could have helped illustrate the convenience of using pre-compiled CSS.
4. Instructor might display a tad more enthusiasm in his voice. :) :)

TIP:
For those taking the course, I suggest learning to use the Atom/Sublime Text editor plugin Emmet. I used it while walking through this course and found it enabled me to easily keep up with the instructor's typing as I could type a little and tab, expanding out what he had just typed in very quick order.

results.content:
This is basically a follow-along of code that was already created before the video was shot. Unlike the good classes in Udemy in which the teacher describes how they arrived at the presented solution, this one is a monotonous narration of how to type in the code to achieve a certain result. You will see a lot of code that you can later use, in a trial and error fashion, to see if you can produce good results, but the course will not equip you to understand why you are entering that code.
I'm also appalled by the videos showing the instructor shamelessly using an evaluation version of Sublime Text, and frequently dismissing the alert popups, in a clear violation of the software's license terms. That license costs $80, so just consider how many licenses could have been bought with the sales of these classes...

results.content: I've quite enjoyed this course. Normally I don't like seeing mistakes in courses, but I enjoyed seeing them here because he capitalizes on them in that they're mistakes you and I would make. You feel at home while he's teaching. Most developers that I know do the C&P from sites like Bootstrap's and then modify for their needs. (Why reinvent the wheel?) This is exactly what he does, and he shows you where to go, where to get additional information on the particular piece of code he's working with, how to use it, and leaves you in a position to learn more by experimenting. I rather like his style. I find his voice a bit droning, but that is entirely me. It in NO way affects his ability to pass on knowledge, and for the user to learn. I would definitely recommend this course to others! When he's done with you, you WILL know everything he says you will!

results.content:
The course requirements in my opinion are higher than what the instructor states. He claims that you don't really have to know a whole lot about bootstrap to complete the course. While I do agree with this the problem I have with it is anyone that doesn't have at least fundamental understanding of things like CSS, HTML and Javascript will not know how to expand on what they have learned in the course as they will just be copy and pasting a lot. There should be a notice by the instructor stating that he recommends supplemental study on these topics.

Also the instructor makes frequent mistakes in the videos which can cause a bit of confusion to any who do not know a lot about the topics outlined above. This isn't a big issue as I don't think making mistakes is a huge deal but I believe that better prep work can be done to look at the material before it is presented to prevent this.

Overall though I definitely would recommend this course to anyone looking to expand their knowledge web development using bootstrap.

results.content:
If you haven't worked with bootstrap before I would stay away from this one if it is your first experience if you are the type of student that likes to code along with the instructor.  A good portion of cutting and pasting in many of the examples (as of this review I am close to 50% through the course), which is fine once you have the hang of bootstrap and we all do it, but if you are a beginner typing it out the long way has its benefits.

He often drops in the pasted content out of place and you end up having to go back and fix mistakes which can be frustrating when coding along which in my opinion should have been edited out for clarity.

Overall it does give you plenty of examples to work with.

results.content:
To start with: I learned a lot. So I have to get that out there. The different projects provide a good look and feel for using Bootstrap, some of them are really great looking, and I've used some of the techniques learned in the course on one of my sites (and have plans for some of the other tools).

The emphasis in three (?) lessons on precompilers for CSS felt unnecessary. I tried working on the first project that used one, and gave up. I ended up doing the project without. I see how useful this *could* be, but the instructor barely scratched the surface, and honestly (I'm a coder with non-web-based but object-oriented software) for CSS it seems like too much complexity for not enough benefit. 

The instructor felt like he wasn't really following a script when doing the lessons -- errors were made (you can edit the video) -- and some things were added as an "Oh, I forgot we need to ..." and so on. That's discouraging at times, and frustrating most of the time. I know what goes into teaching, having been a professional teacher for quite some time myself (just not online like this). The organization really helps ... Getting into the style sheet and just cranking out a huge amount of code without explaining it is also frustrating. I was here to learn this stuff, and it would have been nice to get better explanations for some of the interesting things (like the bubble in the social network project -- adding the pointer to the side) that we did -- so that I could experiment better ... 

Anyway, I am not slamming the course, even though it might feel like it. I really did learn a lot, but I think some of it is that I was already fairly familiar with basic HTML and CSS and general coding concepts and techniques. Someone who had less familiarity than I do jumping into this course might find themselves easily lost in parts of it.

The emphasis in three (?) lessons on precompilers for CSS felt unnecessary. I tried working on the first project that used one, and gave up. I ended up doing the project without. I see how useful this *could* be, but the instructor barely scratched the surface, and honestly (I'm a coder with non-web-based but object-oriented software) for CSS it seems like too much complexity for not enough benefit.

The instructor felt like he wasn't really following a script when doing the lessons -- errors were made (you can edit the video) -- and some things were added as an "Oh, I forgot we need to ..." and so on. results.content:
I like the idea of teaching bootstrap through actual project creation and this course has 10 projects which is nice. However the delivery is very poor and the instructor's knowledge is questionable. There are times when the instructor would just copy and paste code snippets from the bootstrap website without clearly explaining it. I was very disappointed when he mentioned that "sometimes" we have to use the !important modifier for our custom css to work. That is not an acceptable explanation. He should have explained why a specific attribute has to be overridden with !important and not just say sometimes you need it sometimes you don't. Interestingly enough, this concern was asked by other students on the Q&A section and the instructor simply gave a link of an article from stackexchange as an answer.  Just like me, the student who raised that question was not satisfied with that. Why can't he give a direct explanation? Another issue is with lesson 4. Clearly, three students including me are having an issue with the video not showing up and yet the instructor insists that it is working. And when I posted a screenshot proof that the video isn't loading, the instructor just flat out commented: "You are only having this issue for lesson 4." What kind of answer is that? That didn't even solve the problem. 
I definitely would not recommend this course to anyone looking to learn bootstrap.

results.content:
The course does just what it states in the title you literally "learn Bootstrap by building 10 projects" so thumbs up for that. However Brad seems not to be the most patient guy when it comes to teaching, he just breezes through everything, it would have been nice if he threw in the occasional tip or explanation. For the most part you'll have to find your way around because there is very little to no explanation here. 

Nevertheless I didn't join the course for that though, I just needed to get some inspiration and insight into how sleek web pages are built which I discovered is accomplished quite efficiently using Bootstrap. The projects provided in the course are veeery nice and I primarily needed to get access to those so I definitely got what I was looking for.

All in all I would  not recommend this as a first course in Web Design or to anyone looking to learn HTML & CSS you're better of taking another course which tackles the fundamentals. But if you're an intermediate to advanced developer who struggles to come up with attractive designs or just need some nice templates to work with then this course is for you.
